0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Contraception, Female: insert 1 single rod, 68-mg implant SUBDERMALLY in the upper part, inner side of the non-dominant arm; remove the implant no later than 3 years after insertion; may replace with a new one if continued contraception is desired

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: clinical studies have not been conducted in women less than 18 years of age; safety and efficacy are expected to be identical for postpubertal adolescents; use before menarche is not indicated

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• abnormal, undiagnosed genital bleeding
  • breast cancer, known, suspected, or personal history of
  • hepatic tumors, benign or malignant
  • hypersensitivity to etonogestrel or any component of the product
  • liver disease, active
  • pregnancy, known or suspected
  • progestin-sensitive cancer, history or current
  • thrombosis or thromboembolic disorders, history or current

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- increased risk of myocardial infarction; monitoring recommended and removal may be required
  • -- fluid retention may occur; monitoring recommended in women with conditions that might be aggravated by fluid retention
  • -- use not recommended in women with past history of hypertension related diseases
  • -- hypertension may occur; monitoring recommended and removal may be necessary
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- monitoring recommended in patients who develop breast nodules and in patients with a family history of breast cancer
  • -- changes in serum glucose levels or insulin resistance may occur; monitoring recommended in patients with diabetes or prediabetes
  • -- use cautiously in patients with hyperlipidemia as LDL levels may increase; monitoring recommended
  • -- weight gain may occur
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- gallbladder disease may occur
  • Hematologic:
  • -- increased risk of thromboembolism during postpartum period; initiate no sooner than 21 days after delivery
  • -- increased risk of deep venous thrombotic events (ie, venous thromboembolism, DVT); monitoring recommended and removal may be required
  • Hepatic:
  • -- hepatic dysfunction may occur; removal may be necessary
  • -- impaired liver function may result in poor metabolism of drug
  • -- remove implant if jaundice develops
  • Neurologic:
  • -- increased risk of stroke; monitoring recommended and removal may be required
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- use cautiously in contact lens wearers as drug may cause visual changes or decrease lens tolerance; monitoring recommended
  • -- evaluate for retinal vein thrombosis immediately if unexplained loss of vision, proptosis, diplopia, papilledema, or retinal vascular lesions develop
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- use cautiously in patients with a history of depression; monitoring recommended and removal may be required
  • Renal:
  • -- use not recommended in women with history of renal disease
  • Reproductive:
  • -- ectopic pregnancy may occur
  • -- return of fertility is rapid following removal; if continued contraception is desired, resume contraceptive therapy immediately after implant removal
  • -- menstrual bleeding abnormalities, including changes in frequency and intensity or amenorrhea, may occur
  • -- ovarian cysts may occur and may require surgery
  • Respiratory:
  • -- increased risk of pulmonary embolism; monitoring recommended and removal may be required
  • Other:
  • -- complications of insertion and removal may occur; should be inserted subdermally and palpated immediately after insertion
  • -- deep insertions may cause neural or vascular injury or result in migration of the implant
  • -- difficult or impossible removal may occur with improper or deep insertion, non-palpable implants, migrated implants, or implants encased in fibrous tissue; surgery may be required
  • -- expulsion of the implant may occur with incomplete insertion or infection
  • -- consider removal of the implant during periods of immobilization due to surgery or illness

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Acne (6% to 18.5%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Weight increased (3% to 13.7%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (3% to 15%), Nausea (4% to 13.4%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (4% to 25%)
  • Psychiatric:Mood swings (3% to 14%)
  • Reproductive:Amenorrhea (14% to 33%), Dysmenorrhea (7.2% to 10%), Menometrorrhagia (0.8% to 16%), Menorrhagia (15% to 25%), Oligomenorrhea (3.7% to 33.6%), Vaginitis (2% to 14.5%)
  • Respiratory:Pharyngitis (10.5%), Upper respiratory infection (12.6%)
  • Other:Implant site reaction (2.5% to 9.6%), Pain of breast (1.4% to 12.8%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Myocardial infarction
  • Hematologic:Deep venous thrombosis, Thromboembolic disorder
  • Neurologic:Thrombotic stroke
  • Reproductive:Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Etonogestrel is a progestin and is the active metabolite of desogestrel. Etonogestrel inhibits ovulation, increases viscosity of the cervical mucus, and alters the endometrium.

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Protein binding: sex hormone binding globulin, approximately 32%; albumin, 66%.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Hepatic; by the cytochrome P450 3A4 isoenzyme; extensive

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Implantation
  • (subdermal) all healthcare providers must receive instruction, training, and supervision (when appropriate) prior to inserting or removing the etonogestrel implant
  • (subdermal) insert the implant under aseptic conditions
  • (subdermal) insert the implant subdermally in the inner side of the upper part of the nondominant arm, about 8 to 10 cm (3 to 4 inches) above the elbow crease that overlies the groove between the biceps and triceps
  • (subdermal) palpate the implant after insertion to ensure implantation
  • (subdermal) remove the implant no later than 3 years after insertion
  • (subdermal) after removal, measure rod to ensure entire 4 cm device is recovered; if only partial implant recovered, remove all remaining sections

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• pregnancy prevention indicates efficacy
  • all indicated healthcare issues; at each yearly healthcare provider visit
  • lipids; closely in women being treated for hyperlipidemias
  • blood glucose; carefully in prediabetic and diabetic women
  • breast cancer; in women with a family history of breast cancer or who develop breast nodules
  • blood pressure; yearly and more closely in women with hypertension
  • fluid retention; in women with conditions which might be aggravated by fluid retention
  • signs and symptoms of depression; in women with a history of depressed mood.

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
OVERDOSE: Rarely do acute ingestions result in obvious clinical manifestations. CHRONIC: Most adverse effects are related to chronic or high-dose therapy. Headache, dizziness, irregular menses, mastalgia, bloating, depression, decreased libido, cholestatic jaundice, hepatitis, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and thromboembolism may occur with chronic therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
  • Support: Single acute overdoses will seldom result in toxicity. Supportive treatment is adequate in most situations.
  • Decontamination: Gastric decontamination is probably only necessary after very large ingestions or with toxic coingestants; administer activated charcoal in these cases.
  • Monitoring of patient: CHRONIC TOXICITY: Discontinue medication and monitor for signs of toxicity and treat symptomatically. Obtain a baseline CBC and hepatic and renal function tests in symptomatic patients.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
Toxicity is unlikely following an acute overdose. There are insufficient data reported in the literature to assess the range of toxicity in terms of mg/kg ingested.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to practice safe sex. Drug does not prevent disease transmission.
  • Discuss potential long-term adverse effects of hormone therapy including myocardial infarction, stroke, thrombotic events, pulmonary embolism, or breast cancer.
  • This drug may cause pharyngitis, acne, weight gain, nausea, headache, vaginitis, abdominal pain, breast pain, and change in normal menstrual bleeding pattern.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of serious cardiovascular events such as myocardial infarction, stroke, venous thrombosis, or pulmonary embolism.
  • Advise patient to immediately report unexplained lower abdominal pain or signs/symptoms of breast cancer, depression, hepatotoxicity, or retinal vein thrombosis.
  • Tell patient to report persistent/recurrent abnormal vaginal bleeding.
  • Patients should report any unexplained partial or complete loss of vision. In addition, patients who wear contact lenses should report visual changes or changes in lens tolerance.
  • A nonhormonal back-up method of contraception may be required for the first 7 days after implant insertion.
  • Patients should not smoke during therapy, as this increases the risk of serious cardiovascular side effects.
